title: Project Based Development
definition: a coherent, self-contained set of actions, married to a discrete budget and time frame, that are intended to produce identifiable (separable) outputs. Often with a limited time frame and limited budget that hired skilled Western engineers.
examples: Investments in large projects such as building a road, a school or a hospital building

title: Integrated Rural Development
definition: learning from the mistakes of stand alone projects that lacked integration in the broader local economy, the development paradigm shifted, now the idea was not only to build a road but to integrate it in an economic program so as to increase the productive potential of the country.
examples: Alongside the road they focused on the transfer of skills, the building of schools and health centres, improvement of living conditions and so forth.

title: Fungibility of aid
definition: Aid money ear-marked for a particular area can easily be funnelled into other sectors the government has priorities in. Conditionalities of Structural Adjustment Programmes were seen as a way of changing this by tying aid to agreed changed behaviour.
examples: Aid is given to health but goes through a government, which also has other objectives (here military spending) and can take advantage of fungibility of aid. No $-to-$ relationship between earmarked aid and recipient's spending pattern

title: Structural Adjustment
definition: The disbursement of big loans given based on policy conditionalities, attempting to restructure the state through its budget and to redirect state resources towards sectors which would enhance the productivity of the economy. Promoted by the IMF and WB and enforced through conditionalities.
examples: Cuts to public welfare programmes in Indonesia after the Asian Financial Crisis.

title: Conditionality
definition: The disbursement of loans and credit by the WB and IMF was based on the premise of implementing certain structural institutional reforms to help governments balance their budgets. Implementation of these reforms suffered heavily from credible commitment problems.

title: Credible commitment problem (States)
definition: Governments in developing countries signed up reforms in exchange for large loans, with no intention of meeting the conditions knowing that the WB faced a credibility problem –they lacked the incentive to stop aid to countries failing to meet conditionalities. The World Bank suffers from a time inconsistency problem –commitment to withhold aid at t0 disappears at t1.

title: Development Traps
definition:
Collier (2007), identifies four development traps that explain why some countries remain persistently poor despite global progress. These are termed “traps” because they are self-reinforcing: countries caught in them often lack the internal capacity or incentives to escape, and standard development policies are insufficient without targeted, context-specific intervention.
 The Conflict Trap: Countries with repeated civil wars or internal conflicts experience economic decline, institutional breakdown and displacement as they get stuck in a cycle. Countries dependent on resource exports (e.g oil,diamonds) have a high risk of civil war. These conflicts keep the country trapped in poverty. Most civil wars happen in very poor countries, and unlike richer countries where conflicts usually end quickly, wars in poor countries often drag on or restart. Poverty makes it easier for rebel groups to recruit young men who have few other options, and weak governments can’t stop them easily. Wars are also more common in countries that rely on natural resources, since rebels can use things like oil or diamonds to fund their fights.
 Example: South Sudan gained independence in 2011 from Sudan but quickly fell into civil war. Despite several peace agreements, military conflict persists. Its economy is also heavily reliant on oil, however production is disrupted by conflict.
 The Natural Resource Trap: Resource-rich countries may suffer from weak governance, rent seeking and “Dutch Disease”. Rebel groups can finance their operations by controlling these resources, prolonging conflict. Natural resource exports raise a country's currency value, making other exports less competitive (eg. Nigeria’s farming collapse during the oil boom). Resource prices are unstable, causing revenue swings that lead to bad spending habits. Weak governance is the main issue. In resource-rich countries, money is often wasted or stolen, and democracy suffers because leaders use cash to buy votes instead of being accountable. However, there are successful cases like Botswana show that strong institutions and oversight matter. Without them, resource-rich countries fall into cycles of corruption, bad investments, and political dysfunction.
 Example: Sierra Leone(Diamond), Angola→ accounts for 90% of exports but overdependence on oil, neglecting other sectors like agriculture and manufacturing (Dutch disease case, because of overvalued exchange rate that made other sectors uncompetitive). High level of corruption and civil war (1975-2002) between government and rebels prolonged as they were funded through oil money and diamond smuggling.
 Being Landlocked with Bad Neighbours Trap: Landlocked countries face economic difficulties stemming from their geographic position and limited access to natural resources. They also face high transport costs and economic prospects heavily influenced by the quality and policies of their neighboring countries. Significant portion (38%) of the population in bottom-billion societies resides in landlocked countries.
 Example: Burundi is completely landlocked, no access to the sea with no ports of its own. It relies on transit through neighbouring countries for export and imports which raises transportation costs. Burundi’s neighbouring countries: Rwanda, DRC and Tanzania. DRC: Spillover of frequent regional instability from DRC (esp eastern DRC), affecting refugee flows, smuggling and security costs. Rwanda: Historical ethnic and political rivalries between the two countries, resulting in border disruptions and restricted cross-border movement
 Tanzania: Relatively stable compared to the two countries but its transport corridor it's often congested, slow and burdened with bureaucratic hurdles
 Bad Governance in a Small Country Trap: good governance fosters economic growth up to a certain limit, while poor governance can lead to rapid economic decline.The effects of governance are context specific and can be overshadowed by external factors. Reform is possible but rare as elites benefit from bad policies hence corruption and bad governance persist
 Example: DRC under President Motubu- Zaire’s case : President Motubutu had  syphoned 5 billions of dollars from the country into his account by the middle of 1980s. Zaire’s foreign borrowings increased from $311 million in 1970 to $4.8 billion in 1979.

title: Greed and Grievance Debate (Collier, 2007)
definition: Many believe civil wars happen because of grievances (Grievances=repression, exploitation, exclusion). However, research shows that economic greed and the opportunity to profit from war (e.g., looting resources) are often bigger motivators than grievances. This results in a higher opportunity cost for stopping violence. In fact, even though rebels often claim they are fighting for justice, their real motivations may be economic or personal gain. Studies show that political repression, ethnic discrimination, and inequality do not always lead to war.

title: Diaspora Funding
definition: Rebel groups often receive funding from their members in overseas communities (diasporas).
examples: The Irish Republican Army (IRA) received funding from Irish-Americans; Tamil rebels in Sri Lanka got money from Tamil communities in Canada.

title: Social Technologies vs. Production technologies (Eggertsson, 2005)
definition:
Per capita output depends on the country's ability to implement two complementary types of technologies: social technologies and production technologies.
Social technologies describe methods or mechanisms whereby social institutions create patterns of behaviour. E.g institutions, norms and enforcement mechanisms such as property rights, contract enforcement, etc.
Production technologies (physical) describe methods for transforming inputs into outputs but production processes are effective only within appropriate institutional frameworks eg. tools, machinery, production equipments etc

Political will: the willingness of political elites to implement these strategies. In many cases, development fails not because the leaders don't know what to do but because doing it threatens their own interest/power.

title: First-best institutions
definition:
ideal textbook systems such as appropriate incentives, property rights, sound fiscal solvency, competitive markets and democratic accountability. → Western ideology-Follow Washington Consensus blueprint for growth.
Rodrik (2007) argues against this: in the short run, the first best institutions aren't always the best. Given the structure that is in place in a country, one should design policies that match those conditions (hybrid institutions, for example). In the long run, there should be a development towards first best institutions.

title: Second-best institutions
definition: unorthodox institutional arrangements are designed to function effectively within real-world constraints, such as weak state capacity, political instability, or limited administrative resources.
examples:
Successful cases: 
China relied on highly unorthodox, non-standard institutions to spur growth. 
India's (1947-1990) License Raj gradually changed into a more liberal system.
Unsuccessful cases:
Soviet Union tried to implement some of China's reforms in the 80s and did not see beneficial results 
Argentina experimented with currency boards in the 90s –led to disastrous results with highly un-competitive exchange rates.

title: Market Efficiency Models (Sen, 1999)
definition:
As markets developed, so did theories to understand the most efficient way to design them.
Arrow-Debreu Theorem: The traditional model of a competitive market based on 'Pareto Optimality' – a situation in which the utility (or welfare) of no one can be raised without reducing the utility (or welfare) of someone else. This model requires people to behave in a way that is fully self-interested, which is not always the case in real life.
Individual Freedom: Rather, Sen argues that instead of focusing on utility, we should focus on individual freedom: a market is efficient if no one's 'individual freedom set' (i.e., freedom to choose/freedom to achieve in line with what one wants to achieve) can be expanded without restricting another's. This model is more realistic because it doesn't require people to be purely self-interested, thereby aligning efficiency more with substantive freedoms, not just utility-maximisation like in Arrow-Debreu.

title: Market Efficiency vs Market Equity (Sen, 1999)
definition: The most efficient outcome is not necessarily the most equitable; there are interpersonal income inequalities even in efficient market outcomes. This, coupled with other existing inequities, result in inequities in actual freedom. To design markets that leave no one behind, there is a need to simultaneously consider the freedom-efficiency (eg. income-earning) & freedom-inequality (eg. income-using) problems of markets for overall social priorities.
examples: A disabled person with the same income as an able-bodied person still has fewer real options in how they spend their money (income-earning ability vs income-using ability).

title: Public Goods Provision
definition:
Goods that the state should provide for free for all to use.
Need for Public Goods: Some goods are non-excludable and non-rival so doesn't make sense for them to be provided in a market. There are also goods that have positive externalities beyond their strict private provision, and so can be considered to have a public-good component as well.
examples: Defense, policing, environmental protection
Education increases the prospects of the student, but also the society as a whole as they benefit from her knowledge, so there is merit in considering the public provision of these goods too!

title: Consideration for Public Goods Provision
definition:
Fiscal Burden: Public goods can be expensive. Also, (controversial), there is the consideration of whether provision of these goods is really necessary? For example, If some people would have been able to privately purchase these goods themselves, is it inefficient for the state to provide it for everyone?
Incentives: If the pure transfer of public goods are provided, people may have an incentive to not behave productively/efficiently, distorting individual efforts.
examples: Public healthcare, public education

Unemployment insurance (HOWEVER, we also need to consider the fact that employment offers more than pure monetary value, so it is hard to really quantify the incentives of people to misuse public goods)

title: Means Testing
definition: A method used to determine eligibility for financial assistance or benefits by assessing an individual's or household's income and assets to see if they meet certain criteria.

title: Problems with Means-Testing Targeting
definition:
Information Distortion: Mistakes in detecting true need, risk of excluding qualified individuals and discouraging people who actually need it.
Incentive Distortion: People may avoid earning more or hide income to stay eligible, targeted aid can create disincentives to work or improve.
Disutility and Stigma: Receiving benefits may lead to social stigma and loss of self-respect.
Administrative Costs and Corruption: High costs from bureaucracy and the policing of eligibility + Opportunities for corruption when officials control access to benefits.
Political Fragility: Targeted programs often lack political support, universal programs usually more popular and resilient.

title: Capabilities (Sen, 1999)
definition: A more well-rounded way to assess an individual's need; by looking at their extent of capability deprivation instead of numerical means-testing indicators (eg. income). 'Functionings' (what people actually do/become, eg. their level of literacy or health) give visible signals of capability deprivation because it minimises incentive distortion (harder to fake/misreport). Capability handicaps (e.g., disability, age, gender) are hard to manipulate, unlike income.
examples: Less people would deliberately remain sick or uneducated just to qualify for aid.

title: Human Development Index (HDI)
definition: a composite index measuring average achievement in three dimensions: life expectancy, education (years of schooling), and per capita income. It provides a broader view of development than GDP alone.
examples: Equatorial Guinea has the largest gap between GDP per capita and HDI rankings globally, reflecting high inequality and poor social outcomes despite oil wealth.

title: Export Processing Zone (EPZ)
definition: special economic zones where companies enjoy tax breaks and lax regulations to encourage export-oriented manufacturing.
examples: Mauritius established an EPZ in 1970 to develop its textile and apparel sector, attracting foreign investment from Asia and diversifying its economy away from sugar.

title: Conflict Resources
definition: natural resources whose exploitation fuels armed conflict, often due to competition over control.
examples: "Blood diamonds" in Angola and Sierra Leone financed civil wars, unlike Botswana's regulated diamond sector.

title: Flying geese model of development
definition: the process by which less developed countries adopt the industries of the more advanced countries, within a matrix of established trade, investment and power relationships.
examples: Japan's process of development.
